questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a swollen, deformed elbow after a fall.X ray reveals the following.Which classification is used for the following fracture, and what is its stage?
questions.solution:
X-ray reveals a completely displaced supracondylar fracture with no cortical contact, consistent with Gartland Type 3..

The Gartland classification is specifically used for supracondylar fractures of the humerus in children. A Gartland type 3 fracture is characterized by complete displacement of the fracture with no cortical contact between the fragments. This type of fracture is unstable and often requires surgical intervention.




Salter-Harris 3 (Option C)The Salter-Harris classification is used for physeal (growth plate) fractures, not supracondylar fractures. A type 3 fracture involves a fracture through the growth plate and the epiphysis, extending into the joint.

Salter-Harris 2 (Option D) This classification describes a fracture through the growth plate and metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis. Like option C, it is not relevant to supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

questions.text: Identify the orthopedic implant shown in the image
questions.solution:
This is a commonly used orthopedic implant designed for the fixation of intertrochanteric fractures of the femur. It consists of a large screw that is inserted into the femoral head and a side plate that is fixed to the femoral shaft. The "dynamic" feature allows for controlled collapse of the fracture, promoting healing.



Adynamic Hip Screw (Option B) This term is incorrect or non-existent in orthopedic practice.

Condylar Hip Screw (Option C) This implant is used for fixing fractures around the distal femur, specifically the condylar region. It is not used for intertrochanteric fractures of the proximal femur.

Intramedullary Nail (Option D) is a long metal rod inserted into the medullary cavity of long bones, commonly used for diaphyseal fractures. It is not typically used for intertrochanteric femur fractures, although some variations (like a cephalomedullary nail) may be used in cases.


Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557514/

questions.text: A patient presents with a 5th metatarsal fracture. For how many days he/she would have to wear a cast?
questions.solution:
This is the typical duration for casting a 5th metatarsal fracture. It allows adequate time for bone healing, considering the location and nature of the fracture. This ensures proper alignment and support, leading to better outcomes.

Jones Fracture:


  • A fracture at the junction between the proximal shaft and the base of the 5th metatarsal.
  • Treatment:
    • Immobilization: Cast or boot for 6-8 weeks.
    • Surgical Intervention:
      • Internal fixation with plates/screws if the fracture is displaced.
      • Surgery may also be recommended for non-union fractures.

Options A,B and D are incorrect as given above

Reference:

https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/22247-fifth-metatarsal-fracture

questions.text: A man presents with back pain following a road traffic accident. There was no history of neurological deficit. X ray spine is done. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray image shows a fracture at the spinous process, leaving the spinal canal intact thus causing no neurological symptoms.

A spinous process fracture occurs when the bony projection off the back of a vertebra is broken. Hyperextension injuries typically cause this type of fracture and often present with localized back pain without neurological deficits. X-rays show a fracture of the spinous process, but the vertebral body remains intact as given in the image.

Chance Fracture (Option B) also known as a seatbelt fracture, is a type of spinal injury caused by hyperflexion of the spine, often associated with a lap belt during a car accident. It is characterized by a fracture through the vertebral body and posterior elements. On X-ray, it shows a horizontal fracture line through the vertebral body, which might be difficult to identify if only the spinous process is imaged.

Fracture of the Base of Vertebrae (Option C) involves a break at the base of the vertebra, which could affect the anterior or posterior aspects of the vertebra. It may not always present with neurological symptoms immediately but could lead to instability. It might not always be obvious on X-rays unless specific views are used.

Compressed Fracture (Option D) involves the collapse of the vertebral body, often due to axial load or trauma. It presents with back pain and is typically visible on X-rays as a decrease in vertebral body height. In the absence of neurological deficits, this is a common type of fracture resulting from trauma.

Reference:

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S073646791630021X

questions.text: Which area is affected by the fracture shown in the given X-ray?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows a fracture at the tibial tuberosity. This area is a common site for fractures, particularly in younger individuals who are active in sports. The tibial tuberosity is the point where the patellar tendon attaches to the tibia, and fractures or avulsions in this region can be associated with conditions such as Osgood-Schlatter disease.

Medial epicondyle of tibia (Option B) is a bony protrusion located at the end of the tibia near the knee joint. Fractures in this area are less common compared to tibial tuberosity fractures and are typically related to traumatic injuries.

Gerdy's tubercle fracture (Option C) is a bony prominence on the lateral aspect of the tibia where the iliotibial band attaches. Fractures here are less common and are usually associated with injuries to the lateral aspect of the knee.

Osgood-Schlatter disease (Option D) is not a fracture but a condition involving pain and swelling at the tibial tuberosity, often due to repeated stress and traction of the patellar tendon. It is commonly seen in adolescents and is related to growth spurts and physical activity

questions.text: Linear growth of bone is disturbed when a fracture occurs in which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
Linear growth of bone is disturbed when a fracture occurs in the epiphyseal plate (growth plate), as this area is crucial for the longitudinal growth of bones. Fractures in the epiphyseal plate can lead to growth disturbances and potential deformities.

bone and their functions:


Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537199/

questions.text: Identify the amputation shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image shows bones- tibia and fibula. BKA is an amputation that occurs below the knee joint, which is characterized by the preservation of the knee but the removal of the lower leg including the tibia and fibula. This type of amputation leaves the knee joint intact and results in a residual limb that ends just below the knee.


Above elbow amputation (Option C) involves the removal of the arm above the elbow joint. The amputation is performed through the humerus, leaving the upper arm but removing the forearm and hand.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK546594/#article-17484.s4

questions.text: What is the type of fracture healing you can expect in a fracture treated in a manner shown in the x-ray?
questions.solution:
The type of fracture healing you can expect in a fracture treated with rigid internal fixation, as shown in the X-ray, is primary healing.


Creeping Substitution (Option C) refers to the gradual replacement of fibrocartilage or woven bone with lamellar bone during the healing process, often observed in secondary healing. It is a part of the secondary healing process.

Intramembranous Ossification (Option D) This type of bone formation occurs directly within a membrane-like layer of connective tissue and is commonly seen in flat bones of the skull and the clavicle.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented with back pain for six months. Her CT scan image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Spondylolisthesis occurs when one vertebra slips forward over the one below it, usually due to degeneration, trauma, or congenital defects. The CT scan in this case shows the misalignment of the vertebrae, explaining the patient's chronic back pain.


Paget's Disease (Option A) is a chronic bone disorder that can cause enlarged and deformed bones. On imaging, it typically shows thickened cortical bone, enlarged bones with mixed lytic and sclerotic changes, and a characteristic "cotton wool" appearance. This disease usually affects the pelvis, skull, spine, and long bones.

Osteoporosis (Option B) leads to decreased bone density and increased fracture risk, especially in the spine, hips, and wrists. CT scans of patients with osteoporosis typically show generalized bone thinning, with possible compression fractures in the vertebrae.

Renal Osteodystrophy (Option D) This is a bone pathology associated with chronic kidney disease, characterized by alterations in bone morphology. Imaging might show subperiosteal resorption, "rugger-jersey" spine, or osteosclerosis.

questions.text: A patient suffers an inversion injury to the ankle. Which structure is most likely to get injured?
questions.solution:
The anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) is the most commonly injured structure in an inversion injury, as it is the weakest of the lateral ligaments.


Tibialis anterior tendon (Option A) primarily functions to dorsiflex and invert the foot. While it plays a role in ankle stability, it is not typically injured in an inversion injury, which stresses the lateral ligaments rather than the anterior structures.

Tibialis posterior tendon (Option B) is responsible for foot inversion and support of the medial arch. Injuries to the tibialis posterior tendon are more associated with overuse or medial stress rather than acute inversion injuries, which typically affect the lateral side of the ankle.

Extensor hallucis longus tendon (Option C) controls the extension of the big toe and assists in dorsiflexion of the foot. It is less commonly injured in inversion sprains, as it is not located in the lateral or medial regions of the ankle that bear the brunt of an inversion force.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459212/

questions.text: A 5 year old child was brought with the bony deformities, as shown in the radiograph below. It could be due to the deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
X-ray shows bowed legs (Genu varum) in a 5-year old child, suggestive of Rickets owing to Vitamin D deficiency.



Vitamin C deficiency (Scurvy) (Option D): Characterized by weakened connective tissue, poor wound healing and bleeding gums. Bony deformities are usually not associated with Scurvy.

questions.text: In which of the following nerve injuries is the instrument shown below used?
questions.solution:
Image displayed is Dynamic Cock-up wrist splint used in management of Radial nerve palsy causing Wrist drop.



Incorrect options:

Median nerve (Option B): Median nerve injury can lead to Carpal tunnel syndrome. Rest + Analgesics are the preferred management.

Ulnar nerve (Option C): Knuckle bender splint is used in the management of ulnar nerve injury.


Volkmann's ischemic contracture (Option D): Volkman splint or Turn buckle splint is used in the management.

choices.text: Bipartite patella, X-ray of the opposite knee
Fracture of the upper pole of the patella, Cylindrical cast

questions.text: The radiograph below depicts a patient who is experiencing persistent knee pain without any previous injury. Identify the specific condition displayed in the image?
questions.solution: In the absence of trauma with the given x-ray appearance showing 2 divided patellar segments is suggestive of Bipartite patella and the most appropriate next step in management is to take X-ray of opposite knee.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a child brought to the orthopedics OPD with a lower limb deformity and hyperpigmented skin lesions, based on the presented X-ray of her thigh?
questions.solution: Lower limb deformity with x-ray showing ground glass lesion, 'shepherd crook deformity' with associated skin lesions is suggestive of Fibrous dysplasia.

choices.text: Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the type of fixation shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Spanning Fixator :


Fracture tibia, ilizarov fixator (Option A) An Ilizarov fixator, a special device that is surgically implanted into the afflicted bone to give stability and speed the healing process, can be used to treat a tibia fracture, which is a crack or break in the shin bone.


Fracture tibia, spanning fixator (Option B) A spanning fixator may be used as an external fixation device in the case of a tibia fracture to support and stabilize the bone as it heals. In order to keep the bone immobilized, the spanning fixator requires inserting metal pins or wires above and below the fracture. These are then joined by an external frame or bar.

Fracture femur, spanning fixator (Option C) Implementing a spanning fixator could be a potential recovery option in the event that the long bone in the area of the thigh, the femur, fractures.

Reference:

  1. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18978542/
  2. External-fixators

questions.text: A male patient presented with the fracture of Tibia following a road traffic accident. He was managed appropriately, but after 2 days he developed dyspnea, petechiae involving the whole body, and a fall in oxygen saturation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Dyspnea, and the presence of petechiae all over the body in a male patient who has broken a long bone in a car accident could be signs of the hazardous medical disorder known as fat embolism syndrome (FES)
  • Fat embolism syndrome (FES) is a serious medical condition that can occur after a bone fracture or other traumatic injury.
  • Symptoms of FES include dyspnea, decreased oxygen saturation, and petechiae all over the body.

Gurd and Wilson's Diagnostic Criteria:

One major criterion, four minor criteria, and the presence of macroglobulinemia are required for the diagnosis.


Air embolism (Option B) occurs when air bubbles obstruct blood flow, risking organ damage or death.

Venous thromboembolism (VTE) (Option C) forms blood clots in veins, often traveling to the lungs, leading to pulmonary embolism and potential fatality.

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) (Option D) causes high blood pressure in lung arteries, straining the heart and leading to eventual failure

Reference:

Fat embolism

questions.text: What is the method of scoliosis measurement portrayed in the provided image?
questions.solution:
The method of measurement of scoliosis given in the image is Cobb's angle used to measure the degree of deviation and severity.




Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4199170/

questions.text: What is the most common Late complication of this condition, if left untreated ?
questions.solution:
Cubitus varus or bow elbow or gunstock deformity is the result of malunion occurring as a complication of supracondylar fracture of the humerus. It occurs in only the extension type of supracondylar fracture of the humerus, causing a reduction or loss of the carrying angle


Pulled Elbow (Option A) The condition indicates a pulled elbow (nursemaid's elbow) caused by a sudden pull on the arm, leading to radial head subluxation. The classic arm position is slightly flexed and pronated.

Dinner Fork Deformity (Option B) occurs due to a Colles' fracture. In this condition, the radial styloid process is positioned at or slightly above the level of the ulnar styloid process, creating the characteristic appearance of a dinner fork.

Osteoarthritis (Option D) Commonly found in older patients, It mainly affects the hips, knees, spine, hands and feet.

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presented with complaints of pain around the knee along with high fever. X - ray shows lytic and sclerotic bone. His peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. The organism most likely involved is?
questions.solution:
The peripheral blood smear image suggests sickle cell anemia and Salmonella is most likely the culprit causing the joint infection,as salmonella is the most common causative agent for Osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia. Salmonella affects the Diaphysis (MC)

Osteomyelitis:

  • The most common organism causing Acute and chronic osteomyelitis in Adults & Children- Staphylococcus aureus.(Option A)
  • The most common organism in HIV patients- MRSA
  • The most common organism in patients using intravenous drugs- Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • The most common organism in sickle-cell disease- Salmonella typhi. (Option C)
  • The most common organism in a child between 1 to 4 years- Haemophilus influenza.
  • The most common organism in a child following upper respiratory infection- Kingella kingae

E.coli (Option B) causes illnesses such as urinary tract infections and diarrhea.

Streptococcus (Option D) Numerous infections, including strep throat, pneumonia, and skin infections, are brought on by streptococcus.

Reference:

  1. Osteomyelitis (Nursing) - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf.
  2. Common site
  3. HIV patients

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 20-year-old male patient who has been experiencing lower backache and morning stiffness for two years, along with bilateral heel pain for the past six months?
questions.solution:
Young male with lower backache and morning stiffness are suggestive of Ankylosing spondylitis.


Incorrect options:

Tuberculosis of the spine (Option A): Tuberculosis of the spine also known as Pott's disease, is a potential differential diagnosis, particularly in regions where tuberculosis is endemic. However, in this case, the patient's age, chronicity of symptoms, and the absence of constitutional symptoms such as weight loss and night sweats make ankylosing spondylitis more likely.

Disc prolapse (Option C): Disc prolapse can cause lower back pain and radicular symptoms radiating down the leg due to nerve root compression. However, the presence of morning stiffness and bilateral heel pain in this patient suggests an inflammatory condition such as ankylosing spondylitis rather than a disc prolapse.

Mechanical Pain (Option D): Mechanical pain resulting from musculoskeletal strain or injury, can certainly cause lower back pain. However, the chronicity of symptoms, morning stiffness, and the involvement of sacroiliac joints and heels make ankylosing spondylitis a more likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A 28-year old male with gradual progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. Image of the swelling on the x-ray film is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical scenario and x-ray showing eccentric expansile lytic lesion on epiphysis is suggestive of Giant cell tumor/Osteoclastoma (GCT). Management of GCT is Extended curettage and Bone grafting.


Incorrect options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A):

  • Osteosarcoma is a type of malignant bone tumor that commonly affects children and adolescents. It typically presents with pain and swelling, often in the long bones, such as the tibia. Radiographic features may include bone destruction, irregular bone formation, and sunburst appearance.
  • X-ray: Bone destruction, irregular bone formation, and sunburst appearance.

Ewing's sarcoma (Option B):

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant bone tumor that primarily affects children and adolescents. It commonly presents with pain, swelling, and a palpable mass.
  • Radiographic features may show a permeative bone destruction, onion skin appearance, and soft tissue involvement.

Osteochondroma (Option D):

  • The most common bone tumor (not a True bone tumor), usually presents as a painless lump.
  • Radiography shows sessile pedunculated cartilage tumor covered by a cartilage cap originating from the metaphysis.
  • Cartilage thickness > 2 cms is suggestive of malignancy.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who is brought to the hospital after a road traffic accident, complaining of pain around the left hip joint, and is found to have a flexed, adducted, and internally rotated affected limb with noticeable shortening?
questions.solution:
The scenario here points to the diagnosis of posterior dislocation of the hip, which presents the affected limb as internally rotated, adducted, flexed, and shortened.

Classification of the dislocations of the hip:

  • Posterior dislocation: the most common type, often associated with acetabular lip fracture.
  • Anterior dislocation: rare, typically due to forced abduction and external rotation.
  • Central fracture-dislocation: the femoral head is driven through the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

questions.text: A patient presented with pain in the hand. The joints involved were proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint, distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint and first carpometacarpal joint. The wrist and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints were spared. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Involvement of PIP and DIP joint with sparing of MCP and wrist joints is suggestive of Osteoarthritis.


Pseudogout (Option D): Usually large joints of elderly people are affected, most commonly Knee is involved. Accumulation of Calcium pyrophosphate crystals is seen.

questions.text: A maid is playing with a child by spinning him while holding his hands. A few hours later, the child starts crying, does not use his arm, and does not let anybody touch him. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The condition indicates a pulled elbow (nursemaid's elbow) caused by a sudden pull on the arm, leading to radial head subluxation. The classic arm position is slightly flexed and pronated.




Incorrect options:

Olecranon fracture (Option B): Caused due to fall on an outstretched hand or as a result of direct blow to elbow. May be transverse or comminuted fracture. Associated ulnar nerve injury can be seen.

Fracture head of radius (Option C): Common in adults, caused due to fall on an outstretched hand or fall over the elbow. CT/MRI may be required if X-ray is inconclusive.

Elbow dislocation (Option D): Common dislocation in children, caused by fall on an outstretched hand. The median nerve is most commonly injured.


Learning objective:

Essex Lopresti Triad: Radial head fracture + Intraosseous membrane disruption + radioulnar joint subluxation.

questions.text: The following images A and B show?
questions.solution: Image A shows avulsion of extensor tendon at the base of distal phalanx, suggestive of Jersey finger. Image B shows avulsion of flexor tendon at distal phalanx, suggestive of Mallet or Baseball finger.

choices.text: Calcific zone of the growth plate
Hypertrophic zone of the growth plate
The resting zone of the growth plate
Through the whole of the epiphysis

questions.text: Which of the following layers is affected in a Salter-Harris type 1 fracture ?
questions.solution:
• Salter-Harris type 1 fracture is a complete separation of metaphysis and epiphysis without fracture.The hypertrophic layer is involved.

Salter-Harris Classification of growth plate fractures:



Options A, C & D are incorrect as the hypertrophic layer (weakest layer) is affected in Salter-Harris type 1 fracture.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with a proximal 1/3rd fracture of the shaft of the femur. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Interlocking nails are frequently employed for tibia and femur shaft fractures in adults, providing stability via a frictional fit within the medullary canal and interlocking screws that anchor the bone to the nail. This method offers better control over length and torsion than unlocked nails.


Hip spica (Options B) is used in the shaft of femur fracture in children.

Options C & D: In fractures occurring in the proximal one-third of the femoral shaft, vigorous muscle contractions can lead to significant displacement of the fracture. Consequently, traditional immobilization methods such as, above knee slab, and above knee cast will not effectively maintain alignment.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of an osteoporotic fracture?
questions.solution:
Osteoporotic or pathologic fractures commonly occur in the vertebrae, known as wedge compression fractures, typically resulting from a flexion force. These fractures usually maintain stability as the posterior elements remain intact.

Osteoporosis:

  • Disorder with low bone mass and structural defects, increasing fracture risk.
  • Cancellous regions: More porous; cortices: Thinner.
  • Loss of bone strength is mainly due to decreased bone mass and structural connectivity in trabecular bone.
  • Plain radiographs: Not sufficient for diagnosis, though signs like trabecular loss and vertebral compression fractures can suggest osteopenia.

Bones affected in osteoporosis:

  • Vertebrae (Spine) (Most common)
  • Hip (Proximal Femur) (Option B ruled out)
  • Wrist (Distal Radius) (First fracture)
  • Ribs
  • Pelvis
  • Humerus (Upper Arm)
  • Tibia and Fibula (Lower Leg)

DEXA (Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry):

  • T-score: Standard deviations below the young adult mean.
  • Z-score: Standard deviations below the age-matched mean.
  • WHO T-score interpretation:
    • Osteoporosis: Below -2.5
    • Osteopenia: Between -1.0 and -2.5
    • Normal bone mass: Above -1.0

Additional DEXA Tools:

  • Vertebral Fracture Assessment (VFA): Assesses for vertebral fractures using a low-resolution lateral spine image.
  • Trabecular Bone Score (TBS): Measures bone microarchitecture based on lumbar spine texture.

Fracture Risk Assessment:

  • Bone density is one risk factor; other tools (FRAX, QFracture) assess fracture risk based on clinical factors and bone density.

Options B, C & D: Fractures in osteoporosis typically result from low-trauma incidents, such as falls from standing height or less. However, fractures in locations like the subtrochanteric region, glenoid, and midshaft of the humerus often require higher forces. The initial fracture in osteoporosis often involves the distal radius (Colles’ fracture), followed by vertebral and hip fractures if not treated promptly.

questions.text: Identify the zone of calcification in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The provided image illustrates the zones of the physis, with zone A representing the zone of calcification, also referred to as the zone of provisional ossification.




Reference: https://musculoskeletalkey.com/growth-plate-anatomy/

questions.text: In the emergency room, a 40-year-old male patient arrived with a complaint of pain and swelling in the right shoulder region following a fall. The patient's X-ray indicates a tear in which of the following ligaments?
questions.solution:
Above X-ray indicates grade-III injury of the Acromioclavicular joint as per Rockwood classification. In grade-III injury, both coracoclavicular and acromioclavicular ligaments are disrupted.


Acromioclavicular joint injuries:

questions.text: For which type of fractures does the Hawkins classification apply?
questions.solution:
Hawkin's classification is used for fractures of the neck of the talus.


Incorrect Options:

Tibia (Option B): The Schatzker classification is used for categorizing tibial fracture

Humerus (Option C): The Neer's Classification is used for categorizing humerus head fracture.

Calcaneus (Option D): The Sanders classification is primarily used for categorizing fractures of the calcaneus.

questions.text: A patient presents in the OPD after a road traffic accident complaining of being unable to dorsiflex and evert the ankle. A X- ray was ordered by the attending physician. In addition to the observed injury on the X-ray, which gait abnormality is likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution: X-ray shows fracture-neck of fibula, Common peroneal nerve injury is common as it winds around the neck of fibula - which leads to Foot drop (inability to dorsiflex/evert the ankle). Stepping gait is commonly seen in patients with foot drop.

questions.text: What is the most frequent pattern of involvement observed in Pott's spine?
questions.solution:
Pott's spine, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, affects the spine, leading to granulomatous lesions.

  • Paradiscal involvement, the most common pattern, begins at the intervertebral disc, spreading to adjacent vertebrae, potentially causing neurological deficits.
  • Thoraco-lumbar region (D12, L1) is mostly affected, typically in the first three decades of life.
  • Manifestations include bone destruction, cold abscess, and Pott's paraplegia.
  • Spinal TB is usually secondary to pulmonary TB via hematogenous spread.
  • Hematogenous spread occurs through arterial or venous routes, facilitated by subchondral arterial arcade and Batson's venous plexus.
  • Clinical manifestations include a stiff, painful back, rare systemic symptoms, and classical night cries.
  • Deformities include loss of lordosis, followed by gibbus formation, primarily in the thoracic spine.
  • Paraplegia tends to be spastic, especially in the thoracic spine.
  • Imaging modalities include X-ray (loss of plate margins, radiolucency), CT scan (preferred for degeneration assessment), and MRI (best for early diagnosis)

questions.text: Amongst the following, which is the most suitable combination of foot deformities typical to CTEV?
questions.solution:
This combination of foot deformities is typical of CTEV.

  • Equinus refers to a condition where the foot is in a plantarflexed position, pointing downward.
  • Inversion refers to a position where the foot points inward.
  • Forefoot adduction refers to a position where the forefoot turns inward.
  • Cavus refers to high arch in foot.

Congenital Talipes EquinoVarus (CTEV) or club foot

  • Most common congenital malformations characterised by varying degrees and severity of predictable contractures.

Four components:

  • Midfoot cavus
  • Forefoot adductus
  • Heel/Hindfoot varus
  • Hindfoot equinus

Etiology:

  • Maternal smoking and maternal diabetes have strong association.
  • Maternal alcohol consumption.
  • Strongly associated with congenital myotonic dystrophy, myelomeningocele, distal arthrogryposis, trisomy 18 and chromosome 22q11 deletion syndrome.

Pathophysiology:

  • The deformity predominantly exists in the tarsal bones which are in the position of maximum flexion and adduction.
  • The talus is characteristically medially deviated while the calcaneus is in varus and rotated medially around the talus.
  • The navicular and cuboid are displaced medially.

Clubfoot can be associated with:

  • Arthrogryposis
  • Myelomeningocele
  • Amniotic band syndrome
  • Spina bifida

Radiography is the most important investigation

questions.text: Book test is used to assess the function of adductor pollicis. Which of the following nerves supplies this muscle?
questions.solution:
• The book test is a clinical test used to assess the strength of the adductor pollicis muscle.
  • The ulnar nerve is responsible for the motor and sensory innervation of the medial aspect of the hand, including the adductor pollicis muscle. The adductor pollicis muscle is located in the palm and adducts the thumb towards the palm.

Adductor pollicis:

  • During the examination, the patient is instructed to hold a book between the thumb and index finger.
  • In a normal scenario, a person would firmly grasp the book with the thumb extended, utilizing the adductor pollicis and the first dorsal interosseous muscles.
  • However, if the ulnar nerve is injured, the adductor pollicis muscle becomes paralyzed.
  • As a compensatory mechanism, the patient will rely on the flexor pollicis longus muscle (supplied by the median nerve) to hold the book.
  • This substitution leads to flexion at the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.
  • The examiner can further assess this by attempting to pull the book out while the patient tries to maintain their grip.
  • This clinical sign is referred to as "Froment's sign" or the "book test."

choices.text: Traction, POP, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation
Traction, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, POP
Traction, ulnar deviation, palmar flexion, POP
Palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, traction, POP

questions.text: An old lady slipped and fell at home. She was diagnosed with a Colles fracture and managed with a POP cast. What is the correct sequence of reduction of the given fracture?
questions.solution:
• Colles' fracture is extra-articular.
  • The deformity seen is Dinner fork deformity.

Displacements seen are:

  • Impaction of fragments
  • Dorsal displacement
  • Dorsal tilt
  • Lateral displacement
  • Lateral tilt
  • Supination

Closed manipulation of Colles' fracture is by:

Traction + Counter traction (by the assistant)

↓

Palmar flexion

↓

Ulnar deviation

↓

POP application

Management of a Colles' fracture:

  • Closed reduction and below elbow POP cast- "Handshake cast": Palmar flexion,pronation and ulnar deviation (prevent dorsal displacement).

Complications

  • Stiffness of fingers - most common
  • Malunion - next common complication
  • Median nerve - most common nerve injured.
    • One of the very common causes of Carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • Extensor pollicis longus - most common tendon injured.

Options A, C and D are incorrect

questions.text:
After a fracture in the femoral shaft, your consultant instructs you to apply tibia traction. Which of the following will you ask the nurse to provide?
1. Thomas splint
2. K-wire
3. Steinmann pin
4. Denham's pin
5. Bohler's stirrup
6. Bohler Braun splint
questions.solution:
Steinmann pins can be used for skeletal traction by inserting into the tibia following a shaft of femur fracture where 10% of body weight or 20 kg of weight is used.

  • Bohler's stirrup is a device that holds the Steinmann pin and is used to maintain traction.
  • Bohler Braun splint has 3 pulleys and is used to immobilise and support lower limb fractures by maintaining traction.



Reference:

  1. Orthopaedic Instruments - Surgical Holdings
  2. Proximal femoral nail fixation | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org

questions.text:
Following a road traffic accident, a patient develops type IIIa compound tibial fracture. Arrange the following external fixators in decreasing order of their stability (highest to lowest)
1. Ilizarov fixator
2. Uniplanar with a single rod
3. Uniplanar with double rod
4. Biplanar frame/Ring with a cylindrical rod
questions.solution:
Highest to the lowest order of their stability starts with Ilizarov > Biplanar frame > Uniplanar with double rod > Uniplanar with a single rod.

  • Ilizarov fixator: The Ilizarov fixator is the most stable fixator. It uses a ring-based system with multiple rods and wires that provide a high degree of stability and control over the alignment and position of the bone fragments. The fixator can be adjusted in multiple planes, providing more stability and making it effective for complex fractures like type IIIa compound tibial fractures.
  • Biplanar frame/Ring with a cylindrical rod: This fixator provides stability through its ring configuration, with the added benefit of a cylindrical rod that increases strength. The biplanar design gives good stabilization in two planes, making it more stable than uniplanar designs but less so than the Ilizarov.
  • Uniplanar with double rod: A uniplanar fixator with double rods provides more stability than a single rod because of the additional support, but it only stabilizes in one plane. It's less stable than biplanar or Ilizarov systems due to the reduced number of support structures and limited planes of control.
  • Uniplanar with a single rod: This is the least stable option because it provides minimal support and only in one plane. It's commonly used for less complex fractures but doesn't offer the same level of stability needed for more severe fractures like a type IIIa compound tibial fracture.

Reference:

https://www.limblength.org/treatments/lengthening-deformity-correction-devices/external-fixators/

questions.text: When the outer sheath and nerve fiber remain intact while the inner axons are affected, this condition is referred to as:
questions.solution:
• The intact outer sheath and damaged inner axon are known as axonotmesis.
  • Tinel's sign is positive and progressive. It is an axonal breakdown.
  • Recovery is not complete.
  • An injury to the peripheral nerve of one of the extremities of the body. The axons and their myelin sheath are damaged, but the endoneurium, perineurium and epineurium remain intact is defined as axonotmesis.

The Seddon classification is a system used to categorize peripheral nerve injuries based on the degree of damage to the nerve and its components.



Axonopraxia (Option B) There is a partial axonal disruption with no significant damage to the surrounding nerve structure.

Reference: Neurapraxia

questions.text: Ring sequestrum is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ring sequestrum is a type of sequestrum commonly seen in pin tract infections. These infections occur at the site where pins or wires from an external fixator penetrate the skin and bone. The infection can cause the bone to form a "ring-like" sequestrum around the pin, which is a hallmark of pin tract infections.



Coke sequestrum


Ring sequestrum


Tubular sequestrum

Fungal infections (Option A) can cause bone involvement (e.g., osteomyelitis), but they typically do not produce a "ring sequestrum" on X-ray. The sequestrum in fungal infections tends to be more irregular and less characteristic than the ring-shaped sequestrum seen in pin tract infections.

Septic arthritis (Option B) is an infection of the joint, not directly involving the bone. While septic arthritis can lead to secondary bone involvement and osteomyelitis (infection of the bone), it is not typically associated with the formation of a "ring sequestrum".

Acute osteomyelitis (Option D) involves a bone infection, usually caused by bacteria, but it typically results in an irregular or amorphous sequestrum. Acute osteomyelitis usually presents with widespread bone destruction, rather than the isolated, ring-shaped sequestrum seen in pin tract infections.

References: Ivory
